Award.AwardTitle: International Mind, Brain and Education Society Conference 2018

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award to the University of Southern California will provide partial support for the International, Mind, Brain, and Education Society (IMBES) conference to be held in Los Angeles in September 2018. It is a unique opportunity for a broad range of researchers and educators with interest in educational neuroscience to engage with other communities, affording researchers the opportunity to learn nuances of translating their work for other researchers and practitioners, and for educational practitioners to advance their understandings of cutting edge research at the intersection of brain and behavior. The award will particularly support sessions that aim to foster the careers of students and young career scientists and help allay the costs of their participation. The proposal is funded by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, which supports fundamental research that advances the research literature on STEM learning.

The foci of the conference will be: (1) neuroscientific advances in understanding variability in brain development; (2) neural, cognitive and educational ramifications of cultural experiences and socio-economic status; and (3) strengths and liabilities of digital media use for brain and cognitive development, with a special emphasis on math and other kinds of STEM learning disabilities. especially for STEM learning. The conference will together practitioners, administrators, policy-makers, and researchers from a range of different disciplines and backgrounds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

This grant funded the 7th bi-annual International Mind, Brain, and Education Society (IMBES) conference, which was held from Sept. 27-29, 2018 at the Ronald Tutor Campus Center at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles. According to registration surveys, 46% of participants were first-time attendees to the 2018 IMBES conference; 90% of respondents rated this conference as very good to exceptional compared to other conferences.

 

The conference provided a unique opportunity for scholars investigating learning processes to share the results of their work with educators and receive feedback on the translational opportunities for the research, and for educators to update their understanding of the cognitive and neural bases of learning and share best practices with regard to techniques, tools, and achievements. The conference provided a structured opportunity for scientists, educators, policy-makers and other stakeholders to assess the degree to which scientific ideas are ready for the classroom, consider the extent to which further educational research is still required, evaluate the potential of current research in meaningfully shaping pedagogy, and recognize opportunities to use the classroom to challenge the robustness of research. At no other conference is there such a shared base of specialists' knowledge about the cognitive and neural bases of learning and education done at this scale. The importance to the field's health and cohesiveness of this conference cannot be overemphasized.

 

The conference this year focused on: (1) neuroscientific advances in understanding variability in brain development, including new views on learning disabilities and compensatory strengths; (2) neural, cognitive and educational ramifications of cultural experiences and socio-economic status; (3) strengths and liabilities of digital media use for brain and cognitive development, including for STEM learning; (4) exploring the interface between scientific research and educational leadership and policymaking. The conference brought together various disciplinary perspectives not usually present at the same conference, and also practitioners, administrators, policy-makers, and researchers of educational policy. 

 

Broader Impact:

Information from the conference was widely disseminated. Conference abstracts and poster presentations were made available on the IMBES website (www.imbes.org) after the conference. When possible, presenters’ materials were also made available. Following peer review, selected papers from the conference were published in a special issue of the society’s journal, Mind, Brain and Education. Key sessions at the conference were live-streamed and/or video-recorded for audiences who were unable to attend, including classroom teachers, educational administrators and policymakers. A day-long dedicated preconference, as well as specially-designated conference events, provided professional development and science communication training opportunities for junior MBE scholars. Reporters and other media professionals published articles, blogs and podcasts in trade and popular press outlets based on the conference. 

 

Consistent with the aims of the grant mechanism, we collected demographic information from conference participants, though we note that only approximately 2/5 of participants responded. Of those who responded, 26% were from minoritized, non-White backgrounds. 20% were first generation college students. Attention was paid to the diversity of representation of scholar and practitioner identities and genders in the selection of keynote speakers and panelists.

 

Attendees also reported their primary professional roles:

Cognitive/Neuroscience Researcher                                      53.85%

Education Researcher                                                 28.85%

Teacher                                                                                   10.58%

Education Administrator/Leader/Policy-Maker        3.85%

Philanthropist/Research or Training Funder              2.88%
